title: Ezekiel Chapter 23 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 23 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 23 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 23.

questions.question: Who were the two women mentioned in Ezekiel 23 described as?
questions.correctAnswer: Daughters of one mother
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:2 states that there were two women, the daughters of one mother.

questions.question: What were the names of the two women in Ezekiel 23?
questions.correctAnswer: Aholah and Aholibah
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:4 names the two women as Aholah the elder and Aholibah her sister.

questions.question: Which city does Aholah represent according to Ezekiel 23?
questions.correctAnswer: Samaria
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:4 explains that Samaria is Aholah.

questions.question: What was Aholah's relationship with the Assyrians?
options: She played the harlot with them
questions.correctAnswer: She played the harlot with them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:5 states that Aholah played the harlot when she was God's and doted on her lovers, the Assyrians.

questions.question: What did the Assyrians look like according to Ezekiel 23?
options: Clothed with blue, captains and rulers, desirable young men
Dressed in white robes, priests and scribes
Wearing gold armor, old and wise men
questions.correctAnswer: Clothed with blue, captains and rulers, desirable young men
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:6 describes the Assyrians as clothed with blue, captains and rulers, all desirable young men.

questions.question: What happened to Aholah as a result of her whoredoms according to Ezekiel 23?
options: She was delivered into the hand of her lovers, the Assyrians
She was blessed with many children
questions.correctAnswer: She was delivered into the hand of her lovers, the Assyrians
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:9 states that God delivered Aholah into the hand of her lovers, the Assyrians.

questions.question: What was Aholibah more corrupt in than her sister Aholah?
questions.correctAnswer: Her inordinate love and whoredoms
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:11 says Aholibah was more corrupt in her inordinate love and whoredoms than her sister.

questions.question: Which people did Aholibah desire after seeing their images painted on the wall?
questions.correctAnswer: Chaldeans
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:14-15 describes Aholibah's desire for the Chaldeans after seeing their images painted on the wall.

questions.question: What did Aholibah do after sending messengers to the Chaldeans?
options: The Babylonians came to her into the bed of love
questions.correctAnswer: The Babylonians came to her into the bed of love
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:16-17 states that after sending messengers, the Babylonians came to her into the bed of love and defiled her.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 23 says Aholah and Aholibah were faithful to God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23 describes Aholah and Aholibah as committing adultery and whoredoms, indicating unfaithfulness to God.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 23, God will bring judgment against Aholibah and her lovers.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:22-24 explains that God will raise up her lovers against her and bring judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 23 says Aholibah will be stripped of her clothes and jewels as part of her punishment.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:26 states that she shall be stripped of her clothes and fair jewels.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Ezekiel 23:27: 'Thus will I make thy lewdness to cease from thee, and thy whoredom brought from the land of _______'
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:27 states that lewdness and whoredom brought from the land of Egypt will cease.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 23, what was the consequence of their children being passed through the fire?
options: They defiled God's sanctuary and profaned His sabbaths
questions.correctAnswer: They defiled God's sanctuary and profaned His sabbaths
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:37-38 explains that passing their children through the fire caused defilement of God's sanctuary and profaning the sabbaths.

questions.question: What will happen to the houses of Aholah and Aholibah according to Ezekiel 23?
options: They will be burned with fire
They will be blessed and prosper
They will be given to foreigners
questions.correctAnswer: They will be burned with fire
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:47 states that their houses shall be burned with fire.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 23 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 23 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with the temptation to compromise their integrity by following worldly desires. Based on Ezekiel 23, what biblical truth would you share about faithfulness to God?
options: Unfaithfulness leads to judgment and loss of God's favor
Worldly desires always bring lasting joy
Compromise in small things is acceptable
God ignores idolatry if you pray enough
questions.correctAnswer: Unfaithfulness leads to judgment and loss of God's favor
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:37-39 show that the daughters committed adultery with idols and caused bloodshed, defiling God's sanctuary, which led to severe judgment (Ezekiel 23:45-47). This teaches that unfaithfulness has serious consequences.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 23 teach us about the importance of obedience and trust in God through the consequences faced by Aholah and Aholibah?
options: Disobedience brings harsh consequences including loss and shame
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience brings harsh consequences including loss and shame
questions.explanation: Verses Ezekiel 23:25-29 describe how God allows enemies to bring judgment on the women because of their unfaithfulness and idolatry, illustrating the serious consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: A believer asks about dealing with temptation to return to past sinful habits. Based on Ezekiel 23, what counsel would you give about repentance and remembering past sins?
options: Remembering past sins should lead to repentance and turning from them
Sinful habits should be repeated to prove strength
Ignoring past sins is the best way to move forward
God condones repeated sin if one prays
questions.correctAnswer: Remembering past sins should lead to repentance and turning from them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:19-21 reminds how the women recalled their youthful sins in Egypt but continued in them, leading to judgment (Ezekiel 23:34-35). This teaches the importance of repentance rather than returning to sin.

questions.question: What lesson does Ezekiel 23 provide about humility and contentment in the context of idolatry and spiritual adultery?
options: Pride and chasing after idols leads to destruction
Contentment is irrelevant to spiritual health
Spiritual adultery is harmless if done secretly
questions.correctAnswer: Pride and chasing after idols leads to destruction
questions.explanation: The chapter shows Aholah and Aholibah's prideful pursuit of foreign lovers (idols) leading to ruin (Ezekiel 23:11-17, 23:46-47), emphasizing humility and contentment with God alone.

questions.question: A believer asks how to guard their family against spiritual corruption. What guidance from Ezekiel 23 would you share?
options: Avoiding idolatry and teaching children God's ways is essential
Idols are harmless to family life
Family spiritual health is not important
Children should make their own spiritual choices without guidance
questions.correctAnswer: Avoiding idolatry and teaching children God's ways is essential
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:37 mentions that the daughters caused their sons to pass through fire for idols, an abomination leading to judgment (Ezekiel 23:38-39). This highlights the importance of spiritual discipline in the family.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 23 teach about perseverance through trials when facing consequences for sin?
options: Trials come as a result of sin but lead to repentance and restoration
Trials are always unfair and pointless
Ignoring trials is the best way to persevere
questions.correctAnswer: Trials come as a result of sin but lead to repentance and restoration
questions.explanation: The chapter shows the judgment on Aholah and Aholibah due to their sins (Ezekiel 23:23-30), teaching believers that trials may come from sin but are intended to bring repentance.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with unforgiveness. Based on Ezekiel 23, what principle would you share about God's justice and mercy?
options: God judges sin justly but offers mercy to those who repent
questions.correctAnswer: God judges sin justly but offers mercy to those who repent
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:45-49 depict God's righteous judgment on sin but the call to recognize His Lordship (Ezekiel 23:49), implying mercy is available when one turns from sin.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 23 teaches that spiritual adultery includes both idolatry and injustice such as shedding blood.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:37 explicitly states that the women committed adultery with idols and have blood on their hands, showing the connection between spiritual unfaithfulness and injustice.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 23, God will allow those whom we despise to bring judgment on us if we turn from Him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:28 says God will deliver them into the hand of those they hate because of their unfaithfulness, not if they turn from Him but because their mind is alienated (Ezekiel 23:18).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 23 compares the lovers of Aholibah to __________ whose flesh is like the flesh of asses and whose issue is like horses.
questions.correctAnswer: paramours
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:20 describes her paramours with this graphic metaphor, illustrating the lustful and corrupt nature of her relationships.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 23 teach about generosity and stewardship in light of the women's lavish pursuit of foreign lovers?
options: Misusing resources on idols leads to downfall
Spending lavishly on worldly things pleases God
Ignoring stewardship is acceptable in hard times
Generosity to idols is a virtue
questions.correctAnswer: Misusing resources on idols leads to downfall
questions.explanation: The women decked themselves with ornaments and used God's incense for their lovers (Ezekiel 23:40-41), showing misused resources leading to judgment (Ezekiel 23:46-47).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 23 illustrate the importance of prayer and personal devotion in avoiding spiritual adultery?
options: Ignoring God leads to alienation and sin
Prayer has no effect on spiritual health
Spiritual adultery is unrelated to personal devotion
questions.correctAnswer: Ignoring God leads to alienation and sin
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:18 mentions the mind alienated from God due to whoredoms, indicating that neglect of devotion leads to sin and judgment.

questions.question: Based on Ezekiel 23, what biblical truth would you share about forgiveness and reconciliation after spiritual failure?
options: God desires repentance and will restore those who turn back
Once forgiven, sin has no consequences
Forgiveness is only for the perfect
questions.correctAnswer: God desires repentance and will restore those who turn back
questions.explanation: Though Ezekiel 23 focuses on judgment, the underlying message of God's justice implies restoration is possible through repentance as seen in other prophetic teachings (Ezekiel 23:49).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with shame over past sins. How does Ezekiel 23 help us understand God's attitude toward those who confess and forsake their sins?
options: God's jealousy turns into restoration for the repentant
God permanently rejects those who sin
questions.correctAnswer: God's jealousy turns into restoration for the repentant
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:25 mentions God's jealousy leading to judgment, but the final verses show God’s intention to teach and restore (Ezekiel 23:48-49), encouraging the repentant.

questions.question: What practical lesson about integrity and honesty can believers learn from Ezekiel 23's depiction of the women's actions?
options: Integrity is vital because hidden sins lead to public judgment
Dishonesty is excused if no one sees
Integrity is irrelevant to spiritual life
questions.correctAnswer: Integrity is vital because hidden sins lead to public judgment
questions.explanation: The women’s secret sins were exposed and led to shame and judgment (Ezekiel 23:10, 23:29), teaching the importance of living with integrity before God and others.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 23 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 23.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 23, who do the two women Aholah and Aholibah typify in the historical and prophetic context?
questions.correctAnswer: Samaria and Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:4 identifies Aholah as Samaria and Aholibah as Jerusalem, symbolizing the two cities and their spiritual unfaithfulness.

questions.question: What does the repeated motif of 'whoredoms' or 'harlotry' in Ezekiel 23 symbolize in the prophetic literature of the Hebrew Bible?
options: Idolatry and political alliances with foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry and political alliances with foreign nations
questions.explanation: The term 'whoredoms' in Ezekiel 23 is a metaphor for spiritual adultery, specifically idolatry and unfaithful alliances, as shown by the references to foreign nations such as Assyria and Babylon (Ezekiel 23:5, 14).

questions.question: Which foreign powers are depicted as the 'lovers' or 'paramours' of Aholah and Aholibah in Ezekiel 23?
questions.correctAnswer: Assyrians and Babylonians
questions.explanation: The chapter describes Assyrians as Aholah's lovers (Ezekiel 23:5-7) and Babylonians as Aholibah's (Ezekiel 23:14-17), illustrating political and spiritual infidelity.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 23:20, the flesh of the paramours is compared to what animals, and what might this metaphor signify in the ancient Near Eastern context?
questions.correctAnswer: Asses and horses
questions.explanation: The metaphor comparing flesh to 'asses' and offspring to 'horses' (Ezekiel 23:20) likely signifies virility and strength, but also lustful and uncontrolled passions, reflecting the sexual and political unfaithfulness.

questions.question: The phrase 'bruised the teats of her virginity' in Ezekiel 23:3 and 8 is an example of what literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor for early defilement
questions.explanation: This phrase is a metaphor describing the early loss of purity or innocence, emphasizing the severity of the spiritual unfaithfulness that began in youth (Ezekiel 23:3, 8).

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'cup' mentioned in Ezekiel 23:31-34 in prophetic literature and how does it relate to other biblical passages?
options: It symbolizes divine judgment and is paralleled in Psalms and Revelation
It represents a ritual drink in Leviticus
It denotes a symbol of peace treaties
It is a metaphor for blessings in Proverbs
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes divine judgment and is paralleled in Psalms and Revelation
questions.explanation: The 'cup' symbolizes the measure of God's wrath or judgment, a motif also found in Psalms (Psalm 75:8) and Revelation (Revelation 14:10), representing punishment for unfaithfulness.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 23, what are the consequences foretold for Aholibah and Aholah because of their spiritual adultery?
options: Destruction by foreign armies, loss of children, and public shame
questions.correctAnswer: Destruction by foreign armies, loss of children, and public shame
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:25-27 describes severe punishments including invasion by enemies, loss of family, and humiliation due to their idolatry and alliances.

questions.question: Ezekiel 23:37 mentions that Aholah and Aholibah caused their sons to pass through fire. This practice is historically associated with which ancient pagan ritual?
questions.correctAnswer: Child sacrifice to Molech
questions.explanation: Passing children through fire refers to a pagan ritual linked to Molech worship, condemned throughout the Hebrew Bible (Leviticus 18:21; Jeremiah 32:35), as referenced in Ezekiel 23:37.

questions.question: Which literary structure best describes the way Ezekiel 23 portrays the two sisters Aholah and Aholibah?
options: Chiasm highlighting parallel unfaithfulness and escalating corruption
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm highlighting parallel unfaithfulness and escalating corruption
questions.explanation: The chapter uses a chiastic structure, presenting Aholah and Aholibah in parallel sections that emphasize their similar sins and increasing depravity (Ezekiel 23:2-10 and 11-34).

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 23 condemns only the spiritual unfaithfulness of Jerusalem (Aholibah) and ignores Samaria (Aholah).
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Both Samaria (Aholah) and Jerusalem (Aholibah) are condemned for their idolatry and political infidelity, as indicated throughout Ezekiel 23, e.g., verses 5 and 11.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the recurring imagery of painted eyes, ornaments, and stately beds in Ezekiel 23:40-41?
options: To illustrate seductive attempts to attract foreign lovers
questions.correctAnswer: To illustrate seductive attempts to attract foreign lovers
questions.explanation: This imagery describes how Aholibah adorned herself to entice foreign men, symbolizing spiritual infidelity and covenant unfaithfulness (Ezekiel 23:40-41).

questions.question: Which group is NOT listed among the enemies raised against Aholibah in Ezekiel 23:23?
questions.correctAnswer: Persians
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:23 lists Babylonians, Chaldeans, Pekod, Shoa, Koa, and Assyrians but does not mention Persians as enemies raised against Aholibah.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 23 reflect the historical political realities of Israel and Judah's relationships with Assyria and Babylon?
options: Through allegorical depiction of unfaithfulness to God via alliances with these powers
By predicting their ultimate victory over Assyria and Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Through allegorical depiction of unfaithfulness to God via alliances with these powers
questions.explanation: The chapter allegorizes Israel and Judah's political alliances with Assyria and Babylon as spiritual adultery, reflecting historical events (Ezekiel 23:5-7, 14-17).

questions.question: What does the phrase 'my mind was alienated from her' signify in the context of Ezekiel 23:18 and 28?
options: God's rejection and withdrawal of favor due to unfaithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: God's rejection and withdrawal of favor due to unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: The phrase indicates God's displeasure and turning away from Aholibah because of her idolatry and spiritual adultery (Ezekiel 23:18, 28).

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 23 concludes with a promise that the lewdness and whoredoms of Aholah and Aholibah will continue without consequence.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The chapter ends with a promise of judgment and cessation of lewdness, as God declares that these sins will be punished to teach others not to follow them (Ezekiel 23:48-49).

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 23 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 23 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 23, who do the two women Aholah and Aholibah represent?
questions.correctAnswer: Samaria and Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:4 explicitly identifies Aholah as Samaria and Aholibah as Jerusalem, symbolic of the two cities and their spiritual unfaithfulness. This typology aligns with the prophetic use of symbolic names in the Old Testament (Isaiah 1:21; Hosea 2:2-13; Revelation 17:1-6).

questions.question: What sin is repeatedly attributed to Aholah and Aholibah in Ezekiel 23?
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry and spiritual adultery
questions.explanation: The chapter uses the metaphor of harlotry to describe their idolatry and covenant unfaithfulness (Ezekiel 23:37, 39). This is consistent with other prophetic denunciations of Israel's spiritual adultery (Jeremiah 3:6-10; Hosea 4:12; James 4:4).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 23, how does God respond to the daughters' unfaithfulness?
options: He raises up their lovers against them as judgment
He immediately restores them without punishment
questions.correctAnswer: He raises up their lovers against them as judgment
questions.explanation: Verses 22-24 show God raising up their 'lovers'—foreign nations like the Babylonians and Assyrians—to execute judgment, illustrating divine justice against covenant unfaithfulness (Deuteronomy 28:49-50; 2 Kings 17:5-6; Romans 1:18-32).

questions.question: What does the symbolic act of 'bruising the teats of their virginity' in Ezekiel 23 signify?
questions.correctAnswer: Defilement and loss of innocence
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 23:3 and 8 use this imagery to represent defilement and spiritual corruption, consistent with Old Testament symbolism of virginity as purity (2 Samuel 13:18; Hosea 2:7; 2 Corinthians 11:2).

questions.question: Which nations are named as 'lovers' who defiled Aholibah in Ezekiel 23?
questions.correctAnswer: Assyrians and Babylonians
questions.explanation: Aholibah (Jerusalem) is described as doting on Assyrians (23:12) and Babylonians/Chaldeans (23:15-17). These nations represent historical powers that oppressed Israel and Judah, used by God as instruments of judgment (Isaiah 10:5-6; Jeremiah 25:9; Daniel 2:37-38).

questions.question: What is the theological significance of God setting His jealousy against Aholibah in Ezekiel 23:25?
options: God's zeal for holiness and covenant faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: God's zeal for holiness and covenant faithfulness
questions.explanation: God's jealousy in verse 25 reflects His holy zeal to uphold His covenant, paralleling passages like Exodus 34:14, Nahum 1:2, and 2 Corinthians 11:2, where divine jealousy motivates judgment against unfaithfulness.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 23 teach about the consequences of idolatry and spiritual adultery?
options: Destruction, exile, and loss of blessing
questions.correctAnswer: Destruction, exile, and loss of blessing
questions.explanation: The chapter foretells destruction, loss of children, and exile as consequences (23:10, 25-27, 47), consistent with biblical teaching on covenant curses for idolatry (Deuteronomy 28:15-68; Jeremiah 7:20; Hebrews 10:26-31).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 23 illustrate God’s justice in dealing with covenant unfaithfulness?
options: By bringing foreign nations to judge and punish the unfaithful
By rewarding them for their alliances
By immediately restoring them without correction
questions.correctAnswer: By bringing foreign nations to judge and punish the unfaithful
questions.explanation: God uses Assyrians and Babylonians as instruments of judgment (23:22-24), reflecting the biblical principle of divine justice via nations (Isaiah 10:5; Jeremiah 25:9; Romans 13:1-4).

questions.question: Which attribute of God is revealed by His statement: 'I will set my jealousy against thee' in Ezekiel 23:25?
options: God's holiness and zeal for covenant purity
questions.correctAnswer: God's holiness and zeal for covenant purity
questions.explanation: God's jealousy is an expression of His holiness and zeal to maintain covenant purity, as shown in Exodus 20:5 and Nahum 1:2, emphasizing that God does not tolerate idolatry.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 23 reveal about the relationship between sin and judgment in God’s redemptive plan?
options: Sin leads to judgment which calls for repentance and restoration
Judgment is arbitrary and unrelated to sin
Sin leads only to eternal reward
questions.correctAnswer: Sin leads to judgment which calls for repentance and restoration
questions.explanation: The chapter demonstrates that sin (idolatry and adultery) results in judgment (foreign conquest and destruction), consistent with biblical teaching on discipline leading to repentance and restoration (Hebrews 12:5-11; Ezekiel 18:30-32; 2 Chronicles 7:14).

questions.question: In Ezekiel 23, what does the imagery of ‘drinking the cup of thy sister Samaria’ symbolize?
options: Sharing in judgment and consequences of sin
questions.correctAnswer: Sharing in judgment and consequences of sin
questions.explanation: Verses 31-33 use the cup metaphor for experiencing the same judgment as Samaria (the northern kingdom), representing shared consequences of covenant unfaithfulness (Psalm 75:8; Jeremiah 25:15; Revelation 14:10).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 23 teach about the role of idolatry in spiritual defilement?
options: Idolatry defiles God’s sanctuary and profanes His name
Idolatry is acceptable if done secretly
Idolatry enhances one’s standing before God
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry defiles God’s sanctuary and profanes His name
questions.explanation: Verses 37-39 describe defilement of God’s sanctuary by idolatry and profaning the Sabbath, consistent with Old Testament teachings condemning idolatry as spiritual pollution (Exodus 20:3-6; Leviticus 18:21; 1 Corinthians 6:9-10).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 23, what is the fate of Aholah and Aholibah’s children?
options: They are taken and slain by foreign nations
They become priests in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They are taken and slain by foreign nations
questions.explanation: Verses 10 and 47 describe the taking and slaying of their sons and daughters as part of judgment, reflecting the severe consequences of covenant unfaithfulness (Jeremiah 19:9; 2 Kings 25:7; Matthew 23:35).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 23 reveal about God’s response to His people’s forgetfulness and rejection of Him?
options: He allows them to bear the consequences of their lewdness and whoredoms
questions.correctAnswer: He allows them to bear the consequences of their lewdness and whoredoms
questions.explanation: Verse 35 shows God’s declaration that because they have forgotten Him, they must bear the consequences of their sin, aligning with biblical justice and discipline (Deuteronomy 32:20; Hebrews 10:26-31; Isaiah 1:2-6).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 23 emphasize the seriousness of covenant unfaithfulness?
options: By depicting graphic imagery of spiritual adultery and divine judgment
questions.correctAnswer: By depicting graphic imagery of spiritual adultery and divine judgment
questions.explanation: The chapter uses vivid imagery of harlotry and detailed descriptions of judgment to underscore the gravity of unfaithfulness, consistent with prophetic literature (Hosea 1-3; Jeremiah 2:20-25; Revelation 2:20-23).
